unnormalised: So, you wanna up your game, huh? Whether you're aiming for a marathon in Mumbai or just trying to beat your personal best at your local gully cricket match, a solid training regimen is key. It's not just about slogging away; it's about smart work, not just hard work, as they say!

unnormalised: Think about Virat Kohli. He didn't just magically become a run machine. His training schedule is legendary! It probably involves hours in the gym, meticulously planned diets by his dietician, and of course, hours and hours practicing his batting. That’s the level of dedication we're talking about, even if your goals are a tad less, well, Bollywood-esque. Remember "Chak De! India"? Even those reel-life hockey players went through some serious drills!

unnormalised: Now, building your own regimen depends on your sport and your current fitness level. If you're starting from scratch, don't jump straight into running 10 km every day. You’ll injure yourself! Begin with shorter distances, maybe 2-3 km three times a week, and gradually increase the distance and frequency. Remember the importance of warming up before any activity and stretching afterwards. It prevents injuries.
normalised: Now, building your own regimen depends on your sport and your current fitness level. If you're starting from scratch, don't jump straight into running ten kilometer every day. You’ll injure yourself! Begin with shorter distances, maybe two to three kilometer three times a week, and gradually increase the distance and frequency. Remember the importance of warming up before any activity and stretching afterwards. It prevents injuries.

unnormalised: For example, if you’re training for kabaddi, you’ll need a mix of strength training (think squats, lunges, push-ups), agility drills (cone drills, ladder drills) and cardio. And, of course, practice your raiding and defense techniques. Imagine needing the stamina to chase down a raider in the final moments of a match!

unnormalised: Diet is also crucial. No amount of training can compensate for a bad diet. Fuel your body with nutritious foods, including plenty of protein, carbs, and healthy fats. Think about including things like dal, roti, sabzi and rice in your daily diet. Hydration is also key especially in the Indian heat. Carry a bottle of water with you and drink regularly.

unnormalised: Remember, consistency is king! Stick to your training schedule as much as possible, even when you're feeling tired or unmotivated. Take rest days when needed, but don't let them turn into weeks of inactivity.
normalised: Remember, consistency is king! Stick to your training schedule as much as possible, even when you're feeling tired or unmotivated. Take rest days when needed, but don't let them turn into weeks of inactivity.

unnormalised: Maybe consult a coach or trainer at a place like the Netaji Subhas National Institute of Sports (NIS) in Patiala. They can help you create a personalized training plan and provide expert guidance. Don't forget to track your progress. Keep a journal of your workouts, noting the distance you ran, the weight you lifted, and how you felt. This will help you see how far you've come and identify areas where you need to improve.

unnormalised: Finally, listen to your body. If you're feeling pain, stop and rest. Don't push yourself too hard, especially when you're starting out. Training is a marathon, not a sprint. Be patient, be consistent, and you'll see results!
